# Introduction {.unnumbered}

*This chapter is under development. Check back soon for the full content.*

## What This Chapter Will Cover

- Economic growth versus economic development in Islamic context
- Sustainable development and environmental stewardship
- Limits to growth and resource constraints
- Technology transfer and human capital development
- Trade theory and comparative advantage
- Trade ethics and fair exchange in international commerce
- Islamic prohibitions affecting trade (gharar, riba, prohibited goods)
- Aid and development finance from Islamic perspective
- Development partnerships and cooperation frameworks
- Globalization and Islamic economic values

::: {.callout-tip title="Key Concept"}
Islamic economics supports international trade as a means of mutual benefit and cooperation but insists that trade must be conducted ethically, respecting environmental limits, avoiding exploitation, and contributing to genuine development that improves well-being and reduces inequality rather than merely increasing GDP.
:::
